definitions.definition: A lid.
Area or situation which screens a person or thing from view.
definitions.example: The soldiers took cover behind a ruined building.

definitions.definition: The front and back of a book, magazine, CD package, etc.
The top sheet of a bed.
A cloth, usually fitted, placed over an item such as a car or sofa to protect it from dust, rain, etc. when not in use.
A cover charge.
A setting at a restaurant table or formal dinner.
definitions.example: We need to set another cover for the Smith party.

definitions.definition: A new performance or rerecording of a previously recorded song; a cover version; a cover song.
A fielding position on the off side, between point and mid off, about 30° forward of square; a fielder in this position.
A set (more often known as a family) of sets, whose union contains the given set.
definitions.example: The open intervals are a cover for the real numbers.

definitions.definition: An envelope complete with stamps and postmarks etc.
A solid object, including terrain, that provides protection from enemy fire.

In commercial law, a buyer’s purchase on the open market of goods similar or identical to the goods contracted for after a seller has breached a contract of sale by failure to deliver the goods contracted for.
An insurance contract; coverage by an insurance contract.
A persona maintained by a spy or undercover operative; cover story.
A swindler's confederate.
The portion of a slate, tile, or shingle that is hidden by the overlap of the course above.
In a steam engine, the lap of a slide valve.
The distance between reinforcing steel and the exterior of concrete.
To place something over or upon, as to conceal or protect.
definitions.example: He covered the baby with a blanket.

definitions.definition: To be over or upon, as to conceal or protect.
To be upon all of, so as to completely conceal.
definitions.example: Regular hexagons can cover the plane.

definitions.definition: To set upon all of, so as to completely conceal.
definitions.example: You can cover the plane with regular hexagons.

definitions.definition: To put on one's hat.
To invest (oneself with something); to bring upon (oneself).
definitions.example: The heroic soldier covered himself with glory.

definitions.definition: (of a publication) To discuss thoroughly; to provide coverage of.
definitions.example: The magazine covers such diverse topics as politics, news from the world of science, and the economy.

definitions.definition: To deal with or include someone or something.
To be enough money for.
To act as a replacement.
definitions.example: I need to take off Tuesday. Can you cover for me?

definitions.definition: To have as an assignment or responsibility.
definitions.example: Can you cover the morning shift tomorrow? I'll give you off next Monday instead.

definitions.definition: To make a cover version of (a song that was originally recorded by another artist).

(law enforcement) To protect using an aimed firearm and the threat of firing; or to protect using continuous, heaving fire at or in the direction of the enemy so as to force the enemy to remain in cover; or to threaten using an aimed firearm.
To provide insurance coverage for.
definitions.example: Does my policy cover accidental loss?

definitions.definition: To copulate with (said of certain male animals such as dogs and horses).
definitions.example: I would like to have my bitch covered next spring.

definitions.definition: To protect or control (a piece or square).
definitions.example: In order to checkmate a king on the side of the board, the five squares adjacent to the king must all be covered.

definitions.definition: To extend over a given period of time or range, to occupy, to stretch over a given area.
To defend a particular player or area.
The bedclothes; collectively, the sheets, blankets, etc.
definitions.example: It's time to get under the covers!

definitions.definition: The area of the field near cover and extra cover.
The tarpaulins or other devices used to cover the wicket during rain, in order to prevent it getting wet.
